Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Future Directions in Approximation Algorithms Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research is focused on general area of approximation and online algorithms. Many commonly studied optimization problems are intractable, and it is natural to approximate the optimum instead. While there has been much progress on such problems in the past two decades, there is much work to be done. This research investigates some long-standing open problems of interest, it also extends the techniques beyond what is currently known, and the research also investigates richer models and problems that attempt to capture the complexity and diversity of optimization problems that arise in practice. Along the problems considered in this research is that of formulating and solving optimization problems in the presence of partial information, which is often a requirement in practice. Another class of problems concerns the algorithmic theory of finite metric spaces, and this research further investigates the embeddability of graph metrics into normed spaces.

This research broadens the scope of understanding of approximation algorithms for optimization problems by developing models and problem formulations inspired by the aspects of practicality, and by developing algorithms and algorithmic techniques which will be relevant in broader contexts. Research progress is propagated into the curriculum via specialized courses presenting the theoretical advances in the context of their applications, as well as basic courses teaching the fundamental ideas and techniques behind these research advances.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major goal of the project was to study problems in stochastic combinatorial optimization, where we imagine that the inputs are drawn from a probability distribution that is specified in some way. For example, if we were traveling around to do chores, and the times spent waiting in queues at various places were not fixed but drawn from some probability distribution, how should we optimize our travel and waiting in queues to maximize the number of jobs finished by a deadline. We give new algorithms and insights into these problems.

We also obtain better approximation algorithms for NP-hard optimization problems, such as graph partitioning problems. Our approaches are based on metric embedding and linear-programming techniques.

We also study online algorithms, which are a standard model to handle instances where we make decisions about some decisions without knowing what the future requests look like. For such problems, we gave new algorithms for matching clients to servers, and building cheap networks. We also showed how a small number of changes to past decisions (e.g., one old decision changed at each step) could significantly reduce the cost of the final solution.

Overall, our algorithms, theorems and techniques shed light on how to develop algorithms for intractable (NP-hard) problems, and also for stochastic optimization problems. We hope that these will be applicable to other problem instances in the future as well.
